defects.name: Porosity
defects.description: Small holes, pits, or cavities in the weld metal
defects.how_to_identify: Look for round holes or pits on weld surface, like tiny craters. May be scattered or clustered. Surface looks pitted or spongy.

defects.name: Undercut
defects.description: Groove or depression at the toe of the weld where base metal melted away but wasn't filled
defects.how_to_identify: Look along the edges (toes) of the weld for a visible groove or channel running parallel to the bead. Appears as a dark line or notch where weld meets base metal.

defects.name: Cold Lap (Lack of Fusion)
defects.description: Weld metal doesn't fuse properly to base metal, visible as unfilled gap or seam at weld edge
defects.how_to_identify: Look for a visible seam or gap where weld metal meets base metal. Appears as an unfilled channel or distinct separation line at weld toe.

defects.name: Overlap
defects.description: Weld metal flows onto base metal surface without fusing, creating a shelf or lip at weld toe
defects.how_to_identify: Look for weld metal that appears to be sitting on top of base metal rather than fused to it. Creates a visible shelf, lip, or rolled edge that you can often catch with a fingernail.

defects.name: Excessive Spatter
defects.description: Metal droplets scattered around the weld area
defects.how_to_identify: Look for small BB-sized metal balls stuck to base metal around the weld. Usually scattered on both sides of the bead. Easy to spot visually.

defects.name: Burn Through
defects.description: Complete hole melted through the workpiece
defects.how_to_identify: Obvious - you can see completely through the metal. Edges of hole are melted and drooped. Back side shows signs of molten metal dropping through.

defects.name: Convex Bead
defects.description: Weld bead excessively tall, rounded, or humped rather than flat/slightly crowned
defects.how_to_identify: Weld stacks up high in the middle, looks like a rope or caterpillar sitting on top. Profile is very rounded rather than relatively flat. Excessive buildup.

defects.name: Inconsistent Bead Width
defects.description: Weld bead varies in width along its length
defects.how_to_identify: Obvious visual - bead gets wider in some areas, narrower in others. Width changes noticeably as you follow the weld line.

defects.name: Cracking
defects.description: Visible cracks in the weld metal or heat-affected zone
defects.how_to_identify: Look for visible lines/cracks running through weld or alongside it. May be longitudinal (along weld) or transverse (across weld). Often appears as dark lines. Some cracks very small/hairline.

defects.name: Rough Surface
defects.description: Irregular, messy ripple pattern or very uneven surface texture
defects.how_to_identify: Ripples are erratic rather than consistent. Surface looks rough, bumpy, or has irregular waves. Lacks the smooth, uniform appearance of good ripples.

defects.name: No Bead Formation / Globular Transfer
defects.description: Complete failure to form a coherent weld bead - just disconnected globs and spatter
defects.how_to_identify: No recognizable bead pattern at all. Trail of scattered lumps, turds, and spatter along the joint with no continuous weld.

defects.name: One-Sided Fusion
defects.description: On corner or fillet welds, bead only fuses to one surface instead of both
defects.how_to_identify: Looking at a corner or T-joint, the weld bead is clearly attached to one plate but sitting on top of (not fused to) the other plate. May see a visible gap or line where it failed to fuse.

causes.name: Voltage Too High
causes.description: Excessive heat input, very fluid puddle, arc too long

causes.name: Voltage Too Low
causes.description: Insufficient heat, arc too short, stubbing/stuttering sound

causes.name: Wire Feed Speed Too High
causes.description: Too much filler material being deposited

causes.name: Wire Feed Speed Too Low
causes.description: Not enough filler material

causes.name: Travel Speed Too Fast
causes.description: Not enough time for penetration/fusion

causes.name: Travel Speed Too Slow
causes.description: Excessive heat input in one area

causes.name: Inconsistent Travel Speed
causes.description: Speed varies during welding

causes.name: Contaminated Surface
causes.description: Rust, oil, paint, mill scale, moisture on base metal

causes.name: Poor Shielding Gas Coverage
causes.description: Wind, wrong gas, low flow rate, leaks, cylinder empty

causes.name: Excessive Gas Flow
causes.description: Flow rate too high creating turbulence

causes.name: Improper Gun Angle
causes.description: Work angle or travel angle incorrect

causes.name: Stick-Out Too Long
causes.description: Wire extends too far from contact tip

causes.name: Continuous Welding on Thin Material
causes.description: Trying to weld continuously on material too thin to handle sustained heat

causes.name: High Restraint
causes.description: Part clamped/restrained preventing natural contraction

causes.name: Base Metal Issues
causes.description: High carbon steel, incompatible materials, rapid cooling

causes.name: Erratic Wire Feed
causes.description: Liner issues, drive roll problems, kinked cable

causes.name: Moisture
causes.description: Water, humidity, or wet conditions

causes.name: Voltage Extremely Low
causes.description: Voltage so low the arc can't establish or constantly stubs out

causes.name: Wire Feed Speed Extremely High
causes.description: Wire feeding much faster than arc can melt it

causes.name: Stick-Out Extremely Long
causes.description: Wire extends so far it loses rigidity and can't maintain stable arc

causes.name: Severe Equipment/Electrical Failure
causes.description: Major ground connection failure, extreme voltage imbalance, or wire feed mechanical failure

causes.name: Wrong Polarity
causes.description: Machine set to DCEN instead of DCEP for MIG welding

causes.name: No Shielding Gas
causes.description: Gas cylinder empty, valve closed, or hose disconnected

causes.name: Inadequate Corner/Fillet Joint Technique
causes.description: Wrong work angle, not weaving, or poor aim on corner or fillet welds

mistakes.fix: Reduce voltage by 1-2 volts
mistakes.question_to_ask: Does your arc sound very loud and aggressive, with excessive spatter flying everywhere?

mistakes.fix: Increase voltage by 1-2 volts
mistakes.question_to_ask: Does your arc sound stuttering or make a stubbing sound instead of a smooth bacon-frying sound?

mistakes.fix: Reduce wire feed speed by 20-30 IPM
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is the weld bead building up too tall or piling on too much material?

mistakes.fix: Increase wire feed speed by 20-30 IPM
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is the weld bead very thin or narrow with not enough filler material?

mistakes.fix: Slow down travel speed
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you moving the gun very quickly across the metal?

mistakes.fix: Speed up travel speed
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you moving the gun very slowly or dwelling too long in one spot?

mistakes.fix: Practice maintaining constant, smooth travel speed
mistakes.question_to_ask: Does your hand speed vary as you weld - slowing down or speeding up unintentionally?

mistakes.fix: Stabilize your hands and arms for consistent motion
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are your hands or arms shaking or moving unevenly during the weld?

mistakes.fix: Start in a comfortable body position you can maintain throughout the weld
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you contorting your body or starting in an awkward position?

mistakes.fix: Clean all rust, oil, paint, grease, and mill scale from base metal
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is there visible rust, oil, paint, or mill scale on the metal surface?

mistakes.fix: Move inside or shield from wind
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is it breezy or could wind be blowing away the shielding gas meant to protect the weld?

mistakes.fix: Set gas flow rate to 15-20 CFH
mistakes.question_to_ask: Have you checked your gas flowmeter? Is it set between 15-20 CFH?

mistakes.fix: Verify you're using C25 (75% Argon / 25% CO2) shielding gas
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you certain you're using the correct shielding gas (C25 or 75/25 mix)?

mistakes.fix: Check gas cylinder has adequate pressure and no leaks
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your gas cylinder pressure adequate (200+ PSI)? Do you hear any hissing indicating a leak?

mistakes.fix: Reduce gas flow to 15-20 CFH range
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your gas flow rate set higher than 25 CFH?

mistakes.fix: Maintain 10-15° push or drag angle (45° on fillet welds)
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you holding the gun at too steep an angle rather than nearly perpendicular to the work?

mistakes.fix: Set wire stick-out to 3/8 inch
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your wire extending more than 3/8 inch (about the width of your pinky finger) from the contact tip?

mistakes.fix: Use stitch welding technique (short segments with pauses)
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you welding thin sheet metal continuously without pausing?

mistakes.fix: Use a copper backing bar or heat sink to draw heat away
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you welding thin material without anything behind it to absorb heat?

mistakes.fix: Reduce clamps and restraints to allow natural contraction
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is the part heavily clamped or restrained preventing it from naturally contracting as it cools?

mistakes.fix: Preheat material to 150-300°F before welding
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you welding thick material or high-carbon steel without preheating?

mistakes.fix: Let weld cool slowly (cover with insulation blanket if needed)
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is the weld cooling very rapidly in cold conditions?

mistakes.fix: Verify base metal type and welding compatibility
mistakes.question_to_ask: Do you know what type of steel you're welding? Could it be high-carbon or an incompatible alloy?

mistakes.fix: Ensure work clamp has solid connection to clean metal
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your work clamp (ground clamp) making good contact with clean, unpainted metal?

mistakes.fix: Listen for steady bacon-frying sound, not erratic popping
mistakes.question_to_ask: Does your arc sound erratic or inconsistent rather than a steady sizzle?

mistakes.fix: Ensure metal is completely dry before welding
mistakes.question_to_ask: Could there be moisture, water, or condensation on the metal surface?

mistakes.fix: Increase voltage significantly (5+ volts) or consult machine settings chart
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your voltage set extremely low (under 15V for typical mild steel)? Does the arc barely start or immediately stub out?

mistakes.fix: Reduce wire feed speed significantly (50+ IPM) to match your voltage
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your wire feed speed set very high (400+ IPM)? Does the wire push into the puddle faster than it can melt?

mistakes.fix: Reduce stick-out to 3/8 inch - wire should barely extend from nozzle
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your wire extending more than 1 inch from the contact tip? Is the wire visibly wobbling or whipping around?

mistakes.fix: Check work clamp is attached to clean, bare metal with solid connection
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your ground clamp barely touching the work, attached to painted/rusty metal, or has a bad connection?

mistakes.fix: Check liner for kinks/clogs, verify drive rolls are tight and aligned, inspect cable for damage
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is the wire feeding erratically, stuttering, or stopping completely? Do you hear the drive rolls slipping?

mistakes.fix: Check machine polarity - MIG requires DCEP (electrode positive, also called reverse polarity)
mistakes.question_to_ask: Have you recently changed the polarity setting or leads on your machine? Is it set to DCEN (straight polarity) instead of DCEP?

mistakes.fix: Check cylinder gauge - replace if pressure is low or empty
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is your gas cylinder gauge showing empty or very low pressure?

mistakes.fix: Open the cylinder valve fully and verify gas is flowing through regulator
mistakes.question_to_ask: Is the gas cylinder valve fully open? Can you hear/feel gas flowing when you pull the trigger?

mistakes.fix: Hold gun at 45° to each surface so arc hits both plates equally
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you pointing the gun more at one plate than the other? On a corner joint, is your work angle splitting the joint evenly at 45°?

mistakes.fix: Use a slight side-to-side weave motion to ensure both plates get heat and fusion
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you running straight down the joint without moving side to side? On larger fillets, are you weaving to hit both plates?

mistakes.fix: Aim directly at the root of the joint where both plates meet
mistakes.question_to_ask: Are you aiming at one plate instead of the corner/root where both plates come together?
